abstractText: These are the first few folios of a seemingly multi-text palm-leaf manuscript most probably from the 12th century. The opening text is the little-known Hiraṇyasaptaka, a Buddhist ritualistic treatise which claims to belong to the vāriśāstra (?). It consist of sixteen parts with seven stanzas each, viz. nidāna-, jāti-, doṣa-, guṇa-, liṅga-, prārambha-, praṇāla-, pramāna-(sic!), droṇa-, khāta-, digvārā-, maṇḍala-, mantra-, kriyā-, ārāma- and phala-saptaka. The second text, of which only half a folio remains, has been identified by Bendall as the Khaḍgapūjāvidhi, a weapon worship manual (see Add.1706.1). "The colophon itself is dated 311 NS, but a second subscription in Newari, probably referring to a recitation [...]" is recorded in the manuscript. "The date corresponds to February 10th, 1454 (Petech 1984: 173)".
